overview: Ecclesiastes is a philosophical exploration of life's meaning. The 'Teacher' examines wealth, pleasure, wisdom, and work, finding all 'vanity' apart from God. It points to fearing God as life's true purpose.

verses.text: For everything there is a season, and a time for every matter under heaven.
The end of the matter; all has been heard. Fear God and keep his commandments, for this is the whole duty of man.
Vanity of vanities, says the Preacher, vanity of vanities! All is vanity.
Two are better than one, because they have a good reward for their toil. For if they fall, one will lift up his fellow.

passages.title: A Time for Everything
passages.summary: The famous poem about seasons of life—time to be born and die, weep and laugh, mourn and dance.

passages.title: Remember Your Creator
passages.summary: A poetic description of aging and death, urging readers to remember God while young.

facts.text: 'Vanity' (Hebrew 'hevel') means 'breath' or 'vapor'—life is fleeting and often puzzling, not necessarily meaningless.
The book is traditionally attributed to Solomon, the wisest and wealthiest man who had tried everything 'under the sun.'
Ecclesiastes is read during the Jewish festival of Sukkot (Feast of Booths), reflecting on life's brevity.
The phrase 'under the sun' appears 29 times, describing life from a purely earthly perspective.

figures.name: The Teacher (Qoheleth)
figures.description: The author, traditionally identified as Solomon, who conducted a grand experiment seeking meaning in wisdom, pleasure, and achievement.

videos.title: Ecclesiastes Overview
videos.description: The Bible Project explores this honest book about life's struggles and fearing God.
